definition: Unauthorized access to, use, disclosure, modification, or destruction of customer information or information systems. Security incident reportable under GLBA breach notification requirements if affects 500+ individuals or per state law thresholds. Incident discovery triggers FTC notification requirement (30-day deadline for breaches affecting 500+).
official_description: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 8 (16 CFR 314.4(e)) and Breach Notification Rule (16 CFR 314.5), security incident is confirmed or suspected security event involving customer information that creates risk of harm. Security incident definition encompasses: data breach (unauthorized access, disclosure, or modification of data); system compromise (malware, ransomware, unauthorized access to systems); hacking incidents (external intrusion); insider threats (employee/contractor unauthorized access); data destruction (ransomware, intentional deletion); data exfiltration (large unauthorized data downloads); payment fraud (unauthorized transactions); account takeover (unauthorized account access); phishing attacks affecting staff; physical theft of devices/media. Incident vs. non-incident: incident = confirmed unauthorized access/compromise; suspicious activity not yet confirmed may be investigated as potential incident; false alarms = not incidents if no actual compromise; near-misses = educational value but not incidents. Incident discovery: point at which institution becomes aware of incident; not incident date but awareness date determines breach notification timeline (30-day deadline from discovery). Incident scope: impacts on customer information; number of individuals affected; type of information exposed; impacts on systems; ransomware ransom demand. Incident severity: low (limited data, limited individuals); medium (moderate data/scope); high (significant data/many individuals); critical (large breach, payment systems compromise, widespread system compromise). Incident response triggers: formal incident investigation; containment procedures; notification procedures; law enforcement notification (if appropriate); FTC notification (if 500+ individuals affected); state consumer notification; regulatory notification; reporting to board.
applicable_to: All financial institutions; all information systems; all locations; all data types (customer information, internal systems, payment systems, email); anyone with access to systems or data; applies regardless of size or complexity of institution; applies to both bank and non-bank financial institutions
organization_owner: Chief Information Security Officer as incident authority; Incident Commander for response; Security Operations Center (SOC) or security team for investigation; Legal counsel for notification decisions; Chief Compliance Officer for notification requirements; Chief Risk Officer for board reporting; Communications for customer notification; Law enforcement if appropriate; FTC for notification of breaches 500+; State attorney general for consumer notification; Regulatory agencies per jurisdiction

definition: Unauthorized access to, use, or disclosure of customer (nonpublic personal information) causing substantial risk of identity theft or fraud. Breach triggering FTC notification requirement (30-day deadline) if 500+ individuals affected, and state consumer notification requirement based on state law thresholds (varies from any to 500+ individuals).
official_description: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule 16 CFR 314.5 (Breach Notification Rule effective May 13, 2024) and FTC enforcement authority, breach of customer information is specific type of security incident involving unauthorized disclosure of nonpublic personal information that creates risk of harm. Breach definition: unauthorized access to, use, or disclosure of customer information that creates substantial risk of identity theft or fraud. Breach vs. unauthorized access: breach = access creates risk of harm; just unauthorized access alone may not be breach if data not sensitive; access to financial account numbers = likely breach; access to non-sensitive data = may not breach if no harm risk. Risk assessment required: institution must assess whether unauthorized access creates substantial risk of identity theft or fraud. Breach notification rule (16 CFR 314.5) requires: financial institution notify affected individuals without unreasonable delay but no later than 60 calendar days after discovery; notify FTC within 30 calendar days of discovery if breach affects 500+ consumers; notify state attorney general within 30 days if affects 500+ state residents. FTC notification method: online Security Event Reporting Form at identitytheft.gov; form includes: date of discovery, date of filing, number of affected individuals, states of residence, types of data, incident description. State requirements: vary by state; some require notification of any individual affected; some require 500+ threshold; institution must comply with most stringent; notice to state AG required in many states. Breach notification content: required information: type of customer information involved; brief description of incident; steps consumers should take; institution contact information; optional but recommended: institution's response; credit monitoring offer; fraud monitoring tips. Credentialing information breaches: Social Security numbers, financial account numbers (with access credentials), payment card numbers (with security code) = high risk of identity theft/fraud; typically trigger notification. Health information: medical records, prescription information = sensitive; typically trigger notification. Financial information: account balances, transaction history = sensitive; typically trigger notification. Personal identifiers without financial data: name, address, phone number, email alone = lower risk; may not trigger notification if no financial info. Sensitive health or financial data: combination significantly increases harm risk. Risk factors: what was exposed; how many individuals; how long exposed; whether data already exposed/sold; evidence of misuse; Notification Timing: 30-day FTC notification deadline: starts from discovery date; not investigation completion; even if investigation ongoing, notify within 30 days; initial notification acceptable if scope estimated; update FTC if scope changes. 60-day consumer notification deadline: per rule (varies by state); typical practice: as soon as reasonably possible after discovery; notification methods: U.S. mail (primary); email if consent; publicize if 500+ individuals affected. Substantial Risk Assessment: institution must assess whether unauthorized access creates substantial risk of identity theft or fraud. Factors: nature of data breached; whether data accessed/viewed/taken; evidence of misuse; time between breach and discovery; security breaches of similar data elsewhere in industry; Security Event Reporting: FTC portal: identitytheft.gov/bcp/consumer/articles/identity-theft-7-steps-to-protect-yourself-after-identity-theft; online form submission; form fields: (1) name and address of entity; (2) contact person and phone; (3) date of discovery; (4) number of affected individuals; (5) states represented; (6) brief description of event; (7) types of information involved. Multiple Filings: if affected individuals in multiple states and multi-state notification required, FTC notification covers all states. Supplemental Filing: if scope changes after initial filing, may file supplement with updated numbers. No Charge: FTC notification free; no fees. Streamlined Process: form-based system designed for easy reporting. Confidentiality: reporting information not public (varies by state); initial reports may be confidential; public if enforcement action. Breach Notice Content: must disclose clearly and without unreasonable delay; required elements: (1) description of what occurred (e.g., 'unauthorized access to our systems'); (2) customer information involved (e.g., 'names and Social Security numbers'); (3) steps customers should take (monitor accounts, fraud alerts, credit report check, credit freeze); (4) institution contact information and phone; (5) availability of credit monitoring or fraud alert service. Formatting: must be clear; readable; plain language; accessible. Breach Determination Factors: unauthorized access alone insufficient; must create substantial risk of identity theft or fraud. Factors: (1) nature of information (financial data more sensitive); (2) unauthorized disclosure (access not taken = lower risk); (3) evidence of misuse or exposure to third parties; (4) timing (quicker discovery = lower risk); (5) controls in place (encryption = lower risk); (6) similar breaches in industry. Vendor Breach: if service provider breached and accessed customer information, institution must notify; service provider failure does not eliminate notification obligation; institution liable for notification. Forensic Investigation: institution typically conducts forensic investigation to: confirm breach; determine scope; identify cause; remediation steps; preserve evidence; support notification. Costs of Breach: notification costs; credit monitoring; forensic investigation; law enforcement cooperation; regulatory penalties; reputational damage. Credit Monitoring Offer: if breach involves SSN, financial account numbers, payment card data with security code: recommend offering credit monitoring; fraud alert services; free credit report access; credit freeze support. Cyber Insurance: cyber liability insurance may cover: investigation costs; notification costs; credit monitoring; regulatory fines (some policies); defense costs; claim value depends on policy. Regulatory Implications: GLBA Safeguards Rule violation; may trigger: FTC enforcement action; banking regulator enforcement action; civil penalties; consumer lawsuits; state attorney general enforcement; Board Reporting: board must be informed of breach; incident response; notification plans; remediation; regulatory exposure. Customer Communication: affected customers notified of breach; offer of remediation; brand protection; trust maintenance. Post-Breach Actions: improve security; patch vulnerabilities; enhance monitoring; employee training; vendor assessment; process improvements

definition: Comprehensive written procedures for detecting, responding to, investigating, and recovering from information security incidents involving customer information or critical systems. Plan covers roles and responsibilities, escalation, notification procedures, forensic investigation, remediation, and regulatory reporting per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 8.
official_description: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 8 (16 CFR 314.4(e)), financial institution must develop, implement, and maintain incident response plan addressing: detection and response to security events; investigation of security incidents; preserving evidence; notification of law enforcement; notification of regulators; notification of affected individuals; recovery from incidents. Incident Response Plan requirements: written plan; board approval; periodic testing; regular updates; all personnel with responsibilities trained; plan addresses all nine GLBA Safeguard elements indirectly (response procedures depend on design of other safeguards). Plan components: governance (who has authority); procedures (what to do); escalation (when to escalate); notification (who to notify, when, how); roles and responsibilities; timelines; training; testing and drills. Plan testing requirement: Safeguards Rule requires testing at least annually; testing simulates incidents; validates procedures; identifies gaps; evaluates personnel performance; documents results. Plan updates: reviewed and updated: annually minimum; after significant incident (lessons learned); after organizational changes; when procedures prove ineffective; based on technology changes; based on regulatory guidance.
applicable_to: All financial institutions under GLBA; all organizational levels; all incident types; testing of plan mandatory; applies regardless of institution size; small institutions may have simpler plan appropriate to risk/size; large institutions have comprehensive, detailed plans; applies to bank and non-bank financial institutions
organization_owner: Chief Information Security Officer primary responsibility for plan development and testing; Chief Compliance Officer for notification requirements; Chief Risk Officer for governance; Incident Commander (may be CISO or Security Director) for response authority; Legal counsel for notification decisions; Communications for external communication; All personnel for training and awareness; Board for plan approval and oversight

status: Mandatory element of Safeguards Rule; plan must exist; annual testing required; subject to examination and enforcement; plan updates required; effectiveness tested; examination will assess plan quality and testing results
key_features: Incident Response Plan Elements: Incident Definition: define what constitutes security incident: unauthorized access; system compromise; data breach; ransomware; malware; Define reportable incident levels: low, medium, high, critical. Detection Procedures: describe how incidents are detected: monitoring systems; employee reporting; customer reports; law enforcement; vendor notification; define indicators: failed login attempts; unusual access; malware alerts; data exfiltration; system outages; Performance metrics: detection time goal (e.g., within 24 hours); detection accuracy; false positive reduction; Response Team: identify incident response team: CISO/Incident Commander; Chief Information Officer; Chief Compliance Officer; Chief Risk Officer; General Counsel; Communications; Security Operations; Forensics; Information Technology; Public Relations; assign roles; define authority; define chain of command; escalation authority. Incident Severity Classification: define incident severity levels: Level 1 (Low): limited scope, few individuals, non-sensitive data, easily remedied; Level 2 (Medium): moderate scope, some individuals, sensitive data, containable; Level 3 (High): large scope, many individuals, critical systems or sensitive data, investigation required; Level 4 (Critical): massive scope, 500+ individuals, extensive impact, multi-agency coordination; Assessment criteria: number of individuals affected; type of data; system impact; remediation difficulty. Escalation Procedures: define escalation triggers: Level 1: notify Information Security Manager; Level 2: notify Chief Information Security Officer; Level 3: notify Chief Risk Officer, Chief Compliance Officer, General Counsel; Level 4: notify Chief Executive Officer, Board; Notification chains; escalation timelines; Containment Procedures: immediate containment actions: disable compromised accounts; isolate affected systems; revoke credentials; block attackers; prevent spread; Preserve evidence: maintain chain of custody; prevent data destruction; no evidence tampering; Minimize further access: reduce attack surface; increase monitoring; Investigation Procedures: investigation team: forensic specialists; information security; IT; investigate: what happened; how it happened; when it happened; extent of compromise; what data accessed/exfiltrated; who had access; Forensic Procedures: preserve evidence; timeline reconstruction; system logs; access logs; file system analysis; memory forensics; network analysis; Analysis; cause determination; impact assessment; Internal Investigation: chain of custody; evidence preservation; interview procedures; document retention. Law Enforcement Notification: when to notify law enforcement; FBI (if national scope); local law enforcement (if local crime); coordination procedures; evidence preservation for law enforcement; cooperation with investigation. Regulatory Notification: FTC notification for 500+ individuals within 30 days; banking regulator notification if required; state attorney general notification (500+ state residents); notification process; documentation. Customer Notification: determine if notification required; assess substantial risk; notification timeline (60 days or sooner); notification methods (mail, email); notice content; credit monitoring offer; Communication to Customers: clear explanation; steps to take; contact information; brand protection; recovery Services; Credit Monitoring: assess if breach warrants credit monitoring; offer credit monitoring service; duration of monitoring; fraud alert assistance; credit freeze assistance. Recovery Procedures: remediation: patch vulnerabilities; update systems; restore from backup; rebuild compromised systems; testing; validation; timelines. Backup and Recovery: data restoration from backups; verify data integrity; recovery point objective (RPO); recovery time objective (RTO); business continuity activation if needed. Testing and Validation: annual testing minimum; tabletop exercises; simulated incidents; full-scale drills; evaluate response; identify gaps; document lessons learned; updates from testing. Post-Incident Review: after incident response complete, conduct: what happened; what response did well; what could improve; control improvements needed; process improvements; training improvements; Board Reporting. Personnel Training: all personnel training on roles; incident awareness; reporting procedures; phishing recognition; password security; Role-specific training: IT staff on forensic procedures; security staff on response procedures; management on escalation; communications on messaging; Annual Training: refresher training annually; updated on plan changes; new threat awareness. Personnel Awareness: incident response plan summary; where to report suspicious activity; emergency contacts. Testing Scope: annual testing of plan; tabletop exercise (discussion-based); functional exercise (interactive role-play); full-scale drill (simulated incident with full response); testing coverage: detection; response; escalation; notification; recovery. Tabletop Exercise: participants discuss response to hypothetical incident; identify procedures; test knowledge; no IT systems involved; cost-effective; Documentation: testing scenario; participants; observations; findings; recommendations; updates. Functional Exercise: response team conducts exercise; procedures followed; escalation tested; notification procedures walked through; no actual systems affected; cost reasonable. Full-Scale Drill: most comprehensive; simulates actual incident on test system; response procedures executed; communications tested; recovery tested; most resource-intensive. External Testing: third-party may conduct testing; evaluate plan quality; identify gaps; industry standard exercises; tabletop facilitation. Plan Updates: annually minimum; after incidents (lessons learned); after organizational changes (new roles, systems); based on regulatory guidance; based on testing results; after significant security incidents in industry. Plan Distribution: plan provided to: all key personnel; board; regulators (if requested); external auditors; training materials based on plan. Accessible Resources: ensure plan accessible: 24/7 access to incident procedures; emergency contact information; readily available to response team. Regulatory Examination: examiners assess: plan existence; plan comprehensiveness; annual testing documentation; testing results; remediation of testing findings; plan updates; personnel training; Testing in Exams: examiners may conduct own testing; observe response team; evaluate procedures; assess plan effectiveness

definition: Plans and procedures for maintaining critical operations during disruptions (natural disasters, system failures, attacks) and recovering systems and operations within defined recovery time and point objectives. Disaster recovery plan addresses backup systems, alternative processing sites, recovery procedures, testing, and timelines per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 3 (Administrative Safeguards).
official_description: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 3 (16 CFR 314.4(c)(1)), financial institution must develop and maintain business continuity and disaster recovery plan. Business Continuity definition: processes and procedures enabling organization to maintain/restore critical operations within acceptable timeframes following disruption. Disaster Recovery definition: procedures and systems enabling restoration of systems and data after catastrophic failure. Disruption causes: natural disasters (hurricane, earthquake, flood, tornado); technology failures (system crash, data loss, network outage); cyber attacks (ransomware, destructive malware, DDoS); physical incidents (fire, building damage); operational issues (power failure, facility damage). Critical functions identification: functions essential to operations; impacts on customers if unavailable; impacts on financial safety if unavailable; impacts on regulatory compliance if unavailable. Recovery objectives: Recovery Time Objective (RTO): timeframe to restore function (e.g., 4 hours, 8 hours, 24 hours); depends on function criticality; Recovery Point Objective (RPO): maximum acceptable data loss (e.g., 1 hour, 1 day); depends on transaction frequency; Backup Procedures: frequency: daily for transaction systems; weekly for databases; continuous for critical data; Backup location: offsite for disaster recovery; geographically distant; physically secured; Backup testing: restoration testing; data integrity verification; recovery timing verification. Alternative Processing Site: backup data center; hot site (fully operational, immediate failover); warm site (equipment ready, configuration required); cold site (equipment available, setup required); geographic diversity (different location to survive regional disaster); Fail-over Capability: automated failover for critical systems; manual failover for others; testing of failover; recovery procedures documented. System Recovery: rebuild procedures; alternate systems; recovery sequence; validation; testing; timelines per RTO. Data Recovery: data restoration from backup; data integrity verification; version control; recovery from specific point in time per RPO. Customer Access: ensure customer access continues: alternate channels (phone, alternate systems); communications to customers; transaction processing continues. Testing and Validation: annual testing minimum; test backup restoration; test failover; test recovery procedures; test alternative site; validate timelines meet RTO/RPO; documented results; remediation of deficiencies. Documentation: plan documented; procedures detailed; recovery steps; contact information; system documentation; data center documentation. Personnel Training: key personnel training on: roles and responsibilities; recovery procedures; evacuation procedures; emergency communication; regular refresher training. Communication Plan: notification procedures during outage; stakeholder communication (customers, employees, regulators); status updates. Regulatory Examination: examiners assess: plan documentation; criticality assessment; backup procedures; alternative site; testing results; RTO/RPO appropriateness; recovery effectiveness
